questiontext.text: Sort the following countries according to when they conducted their first nuclear weapon test.

Fill in the blanks below with words from this box:

critical mass - full-scaled - cold - weapon designs - yield - virtual testing - reprocessing plants - supercomputers - stockpile - conventional - physical

Not all nuclear weapons tests are {1:SHORTANSWER:=full-scaled~=full scaled} tests. Sub-critical (or "{1:SHORTANSWER:=cold}") experiments are nuclear weapons-related tests without a {1:SHORTANSWER:=critical mass} of fissile material so that no {1:SHORTANSWER:=yield} results from the test. Nuclear explosions can, to a certain degree, also be simulated on {1:SHORTANSWER:=supercomputers}. Such "{1:SHORTANSWER:=virtual testing}" allows maintaining the {1:SHORTANSWER:=stockpile} without the need for {1:SHORTANSWER:=physical} tests. Whether virtual testing also enables the validation of entirely new {1:SHORTANSWER:=weapon designs~=weapon design} is contested.
What is nuclear fission?

answer.text: The separation of electrons and protons within an atom
The collision of elementary particles in a particle accelerator

questiontext.text: What is meant by 'critical mass'?

answer.text: The maximum amount of fissile material within a nuclear device
The minimum amount of fissile material needed to sustain a nuclear chain reaction

questiontext.text: The Nagasaki bomb weighed 4 tons and contained about 8 kg of plutonium [Pu]. The yield of the bomb was approximately 21 kilotons. Which statements about the Nagasaki bomb are correct?

answer.text: It discharged an amount of destructive energy equivalent to 21,000 tons of conventional TNT

questiontext.text: Which of the following effects is characteristic for a nuclear, but not for a conventional explosive device?
Which two countries possess the largest nuclear arsenals and produced the highest amount of fissile material?
Which country neither denies nor confirms its nuclear arsenal?
Besides its use in nuclear weapons, HEU can also be used...

answer.text: in special reactors designed for the production of medical isotope.

questiontext.text: The scope of a Fissile Material Cut-Off Treaty (FMCT)...

answer.text: is still contested and has not yet been agreed upon.
comprises all fissile materials for weapon purposes.
comprises only future stocks of fissile materials, but would not include existing stocks.
includes only HEU and weapon grade plutonium, but not reactor plutonium.

questiontext.text: Which of the following are purposes of testing nuclear weapons?

answer.text: Confirming the reliability and safety of existing nuclear stockpiles
Improving warhead designs, for example the yield-to-weight ratio
Sending a political signal, for example declaring yourself a nuclear power

questiontext.text: Which tests are banned by the CTBT?
The 1963 "Hotline" between the US and the Soviet Union/Russia…

answer.text: still exists today in the form of email and instant messenger.
consisted of red telephones in the Kremlin and the White House.
was actually never used in times of crises.
was the very first bilateral arms control instrument.

questiontext.text: The Anti-Ballistic Missile (ABM)-Treaty…

answer.text: is often referred to as the "cornerstone of Cold war strategic stability".
was negotiated between Presidents Reagan and Gorbatchev.

questiontext.text: Which of the following statements are true?

answer.text: SALT I for the first time limited the build-up of nuclear weapons stockpiles.
The INF Treaty prohibts all ground-launched missiles with ranges of between 500 and 5,500 km.
New START for the first time inlcudes China in an strategic arms reductions treaty.

questiontext.text: What is prohibited under the 1987 INF Treaty?

answer.text: The deployment of ground-launched intermediate-range ballistic missiles (IRBMs).
The testing of sea-based ballistic missile defense systems against short-range missiles.
The testing of ground-based launchers for ballistic missiles with ranges of 750 km.

questiontext.text: Proponents of US-Soviet bilateral arms control argued that arms control…

answer.text: decreased the risk of inadvertent nuclear war.

questiontext.text: The CTBT…

answer.text: is the first treaty banning nuclear weapons tests.
is signed and ratified by a majority of countries.

questiontext.text: Which observational technologies are used by the CTBTO's International Monitoring System (IMS) to detect nuclear tests?
What is meant by Presidential Nuclear Initiatives (PNI)?

answer.text: Negotiations between the US/Russia and other nuclear powers on the multilateralization of strategic nuclear arms control
Talks between Presidents Reagan and Gorbatchev in the 1980s on eliminating all nuclear weapons

questiontext.text: The nuclear fuel cycle…
What is a typical yield of modern thermonuclear weapons?
Which effects could a large-scale nuclear weapons exchange have on the environment?
How many nuclear weapon tests were conducted worldwide over the decades?
Which tests are banned by the CTBT?
Nuclear weapons were tested in the past in order to…

answer.text: Confirm the reliability and safety of existing nuclear stockpiles
Improve warhead designs, for example the yield-to-weight ratio
Send a political signal to strategic rivals

questiontext.text: In which city does the CTBTO (Preparatory Commission) reside?
What is the main purpose of a reprocessing plant?

answer.text: To recover the highly-enriched uranium from spent nuclear fuel
To recover plutonium from spent nuclear fuel
To recover caesium from spent nuclear fuel for use in medical applications
To separate unstable plutonium isotopes from stable plutonium isotopes

questiontext.text: When uranium is enriched, it is typically in which state of matter?
A nuclear weapon can also be manufactured with half a critical mass of highly-enriched uranium mixed with half a critical mass of plutonium.
